Review Title: Kitchen creative. Waiters speak incomprehensible English. Sommelier doesn't explain the wines. Toilets dirty.
Review Text: Food creative. Waiters speak incomprehensible English. The sommelier doesn't explain the wines. As the evening progressed, the toilets became worse and worse. Out of the bad box came upscale department store music. If you want to appeal to all the senses.....

We went to this little restaurant because it was not far from our favorite museum. 
We were not disappointed. I had the chance to taste the best non-alcoholic food pairing since this proposal is made in some restaurants. For once, it was not fruit juices but worked drinks, in the noble sense of the word, that matched perfectly with the dishes of the chef. On the quality of the food, nothing wrong. The 2 stars are well deserved
This was our fourth time here and a very disappointing experience.  Service was very cold and impersonal compared to our first three visits.  Food was very good but not quite as good or as creative.
A superb experience in the very clean setting of David Toutain's Michelin-starred restaurant. A superb culinary discovery.

Disappointed by the quality of service. You'd expect better in a two macaroons, especially considering the price. 
Restaurant full of American tourists. Warning.
We're not going back.

Modern setting a little sad all the same….
Spaced tables, good atmosphere, friendly and efficient service. 
Everything that was offered to us was incredible and for me it was a unique experience. 
All the products used are of perfect quality, the combinations, cooking, seasonings and dressings of extremely rare originality and research. 
It’s an unforgettable taste moment. 
The wine list is very rich and varied. 
The bill is very high but perfectly justified given the service. 
Congratulations to the chef and his entire team.

Review Title: High-level Talent with Questionable  Restaurant Practices
Review Text: The Chef is among the most sophisticated in the city--innovative,  imaginative, and a master with vegetables.  Most of what we ate was delicious and expanded our taste experience.  The opening oyster with raspberry and shallot cream and the pumpkin seed "focaccia", with bay leaf and a wonderful combination of butter and olive oil, were both inspired.  An asparagus spear with almond foam and a touch of rhubarb played off rich and tart flavors in a subtle way.  The chef's signature smoked herring in black sesame sauce covering diced apple was a wonder.  We found the abalone with seaweed puree and seaweed butter, enhanced by minty herb, only slightly less perfect.  The final main, a medium rare duck in an orange and onion flavored sauce, with asparagus, tasted good.  But in relation to the rest of the meal, it  was a jolt.  Instead of imaginative and innovative, it seemed just a good version of something familiar.  Moreover, the duck was chewy.  This was a real come-down from the string of preceding, near perfect, innovative dishes.  Dessert was also mixed.  The strawberries marinated and glazed with strawberry and elderberry juice with almond sorbet were marvelous; but the  traditional strawberry tart was bland and uninteresting, another miscalculation.  Finishing bites were very good and innovative, except that the crepe with pecan cream seemed a bit heavy for a finish.  So mostly, a terrific meal with some surprising lapses.  It was fun to have a window on the chefs working in the kitchen.  Decor is tasteful and attractive.  Noise level too high, though not oppressive.  Our main criticism was of the service.  Although friendly, it was not graceful.  One waiter dropped food on the table behind us.  We had to wait puzzlingly long for our coats. After declaring that we did not want any of the offered extras, beyond the tasting menu, a waiter intentionally left an open caviar tin on the table.  So we had to reject it again. More worrisome: in an apple sorbet, palate-cleanser after the main course, we were offered an alcoholic calvados or non-alcoholic calvados syrup.  There was no indication that the alcoholic choice cost extra (it cost 48E for two, we learned  later).  The couple at the table next to us complained about the charge at length, when they were presented with the bill; so we know that we were not alone in being misled.  I made the point, but did not belabor it, and paid up.  In many fine-dining experiences in Paris (1-, 2-, and 3- michelin star restaurants) over many years, this sort of thing has never happened.  A chef of Toutain's talent should not be associated with such  practices.  All of this left a bad aftertaste in what should have been a fine meal.  Most of the food was at a very very high level, but meals should be more than showcases of talent.  They should be an occasion for fellow-feeling, not for feeling that one has been misled for extra Euros.

Review Title: Mediocre  food great wine terrible service
Review Text: Goodamusebouches.  Blandundercookedfood..   Terrible service with long gaps between courses and no replenishment of water. Great wines at reasonable prices. Quality Variable.

Dinner for my birthday offered by my partner. It was really perfect. We had the menu in 8 sequences as well as a superb discovery with a bottle of wine on the advice of the sommelier to accompany us. We never lack water or bread. The staff is smiling and friendly, it's very pleasant. And obviously the kitchen! My partner, who doesn't like shellfish at all, was able to discover and appreciate seafood. The combination of flavors and textures is so creative, it's WOAW. They put glitter in our eyes from start to finish!

The thing I most looked forward to, on this first trip to Paris after a long, pandemic-fueled travel hiatus, was David Toutain.  It's long been my favorite Paris restaurant.  It earned a second Michelin star since we ere last there, so what could it do but be even better?  What a disappointment.  The tasting menu was fairly pedestrian, and the presentation was lackluster and unenthusiastic.  The white burgundy was not kept cool, so that two hours into the long meal, it was actually WARM - not "room temperature." Why?  There's just no excuse for indifferent service.  The waiter stopped pouring the wine at one point, for reasons known only to him. My companion chastised me for not asking for more wine.  I don't expect to have to ask that a waiter notice an empty wine glass.  The room, which used to be warm  - even whimsical - is now cold and staid.

Review Title: Don’t waste your money and time here
Review Text:
Please save your money and go somewhere else.

For two Michelin star restaurant, the service was terrible. 

We were constantly thirsty because our glasses were not refilled and we wanted to order more wine bottles but our waiter never came around. The service is painfully slow and the food came out at a random SLOW pace. It took total of four hours to finish the course and at the end we were so irritated because we were mostly bored and trying to get the waiter to refill our drinks. 

The waiter didn’t speak good English so when he explained the dish, none of us understood what he was saying. 

Such a huge disappointment and wish that we went to a different restaurant

It makes me sad to conclude that the Little Price, with all his whimsy, ability for delight and engaging charm, has sadly  turned into St. Exuprey's Business, Man.

In the past every aspect of Toutain's  restaurant was a delight: the uniqueness of each course, the whimsey  of the plates on which it was served, the  variety and uniqueness of each bite, the joy of the wait staff......

No restaurant, "on any planet",  had that charm.

The restaurant now has two stars instead of one. We are served by serious men in suits, who present as if they are tired  of what they are describing, one course is too much like the other. Subtle variety is a gift  but this was not it.

The negative I am trying to convey is this could be any fine restaurant, in any country or city. The price no different from many  fine restaurants,  but as the Little Price would put it, it has ceased to be "unique in all the world".

Simply amazing from start to finish! Refined and superbly presented with a fine service. The chef has matured since the agapé substance, his cuisine has a real visual and taste identity, we love it!! See you soon before the third 😉
enjoyed my time at the restaurant with his subtle style of cuisine and philosophy with a deep root of french cuisine philosophy.

It’s definitely a must go to. Every dish on its own is an experience. The taste, plates and how beautiful they are is just on another level. I was impressed by how creative and delicious it was. Aside from the beautiful plates that we kept receiving. No need to say I was full to the max by the end

Never disappointed at David Toutain
Warm welcome then once at the table we are carried away by the flavors of the dishes from start to finish
Lots of inspiration from the chef
We recommend it to you with your eyes closed
Congratulations keep this momentum going
AP

First experience at David Toutain and a little disappointed.
The setting is quite cold. The service is attentive and sometimes a little too present.
The cuisine, as inventive as it was, lacked personality for my taste.
Few remarkable flavors compared to other starred ones.
Beautiful and good wine list.
A decent overall experience but can do better with regard to the 2 stars.

Very disappointed. The service is really not up to two-star standards: cutlery falling from the waiter's hands, sauce dripping on the table. We ask for the bread several times before it arrives. The waiter walks in front of you to serve you wine. He interferes in our conversations and gives us his opinion. And the worst part, he asks me if I have any allergies. I answer “yes, shellfish”. A quarter of an hour later, they bring me shrimp! The products are, however, well crafted. Lots of vegetables, few noble products. This is very expensive for what it is. The bread is very ordinary, the toilets are dirty, the music doesn't help. This restaurant lacks class. Damage.

To properly celebrate our meeting, a 2* was essential. And we were not disappointed because from the appetizers to the café, everything was original, tasty, refined. Tasting 8 dishes not to be missed.

Our expectations for a two star restaurant were high, but it was very disappointing. The moctail was very simple, there was no choice and there was no non-alcoholic beer and the white wine by the glass was extremely poor. The dishes were not up to standard, no palette of flavors and little variation of structure. Some dishes tasteless. David was not present to discuss our dissatisfaction. Compared to our experiences in many other Michelin-starred restaurants, this was not worth the stars.
Not cheap but worth every penny. Friendly and knowledgable staff.  Food and wine were deserving of the Michelin stars. Lives up to its reputation. Highly recommended.

Review Title: The best meal I've ever had.
Review Text: WOW!  What an exceptional experience.  Absolutely worth every penny.  We had such a wonderful meal, each and every item was delicious.  Both my husband and I commented frequently that we could eat a whole lot more of that or settle for licking our plates.  Most items were an evolution from entering the mouth to the finish.  Such complex flavors.  We had dinner with the wine pairing, which included cider and saki, as well as untold wines, and it was fabulous.  We will cherish this experience the rest of our lives.  The atmosphere and staff are exceptional.

We chose the Meadowsweet menu; everything was beautiful, succulent, surprising and of high quality. The service was a little below what I see in starred restaurants but what partly ruined our evening was the atmosphere of the station hall in the dining room. Is it the lack of embarrassment of the one-night guests or the relaxed atmosphere of the establishment that encourages this type of behavior? For these reasons I will probably recommend it to my friends with moderate enthusiasm.
We had the 10 course tasting menu. It was delicious and very creative. Definitely come hungry, because you will get plenty of food.

Some signature dishes like hare and eel but sometimes we are drowned in the multiple flavors without general unity of the cuisine or the menu. The extra lobster adds nothing (apart from the cost) to the meal which is already stretching. The salmon is confusingly ordinary and we would have liked to find a slightly more original fish for such an expensive 2-star with slow and laborious service.
